  3. You can report the violation to the National Consumer Helpline by dialing 1915.

practice_questions.question: A shopkeeper charges ₹35 for a cookie packet with an MRP of ₹40. Is this legal?
practice_questions.answer: Yes, it is legal because the price charged is less than the MRP.

subtopics.title: Day 3: Right to Safety
subtopics.content:
Your Right to Be Protected

The Right to Safety means that the goods you buy should not cause harm to your health or life. This is one of your most fundamental rights as a consumer.

How to Check for Safety:

  • Check Expiry Dates: Never buy food or medicines that are past their expiry date.
  • Look for Safety Marks: These are official certifications that a product has met safety standards. Common marks include:
    • ISI: For electrical appliances.
    • Agmark: For agricultural products like honey or spices.
    • Hallmark: For the purity of gold jewelry.
  • Inspect Packaging: Look for any signs of damage or tampering.

What to Do with Unsafe Products:

If you buy a product that you believe is unsafe, stop using it immediately, keep the receipt, and report it. Reporting not only helps you, but it also protects other consumers.

practice_questions.question: Which safety mark should you look for on an electric iron?
practice_questions.answer: The ISI mark.

subtopics.title: Day 4: Right to Choose
subtopics.content:
Freedom in the Marketplace

The Right to Choose means you have the freedom to select from a variety of products and services at competitive prices. A seller cannot force you to buy something you don't want.

Why Choice Matters:

When businesses have to compete for your money, it leads to:

  • Better prices
  • Higher quality products
  • More innovation
  • Improved customer service

Threats to Your Choice:

  • Forced Bundling: When a seller forces you to buy a second product (like a phone case) to get the product you actually want (the phone). This is an unfair trade practice.
  • Limited Options: A shop intentionally stocking only one brand to push its sale.

As a smart consumer, always compare your options and resist pressure to make a purchase.

practice_questions.question: A shopkeeper says you must buy a specific phone case with a new phone. Does this violate your rights?
practice_questions.answer: Yes, this is forced bundling and violates your Right to Choose.

subtopics.title: Day 5: Right to Refund and Compensation
subtopics.content:
Getting What You Paid For

If a product is defective or a service is poor, you have the Right to Seek Redressal. This means you can seek a remedy, which could be a refund, replacement, repair, or even monetary compensation for any loss or injury.

When Can You Claim a Remedy?

  • The product is defective (e.g., a new pen that doesn't write).
  • The service paid for was not provided properly.
  • The product is unsafe and caused you harm.
  • The quantity is less than what you paid for.

How to Claim Your Right:

  1. Keep Proof: Always keep receipts, warranty cards, and photos/videos of the defect. This is your most important evidence.
  2. Contact the Seller: First, approach the seller politely with your proof and ask for a resolution.
  3. Escalate: If the seller doesn't help, you can file a complaint with a consumer forum or call the helpline (1915).

practice_questions.question: You bought a new pen that doesn't write. What is the first step you should take?
practice_questions.answer: The first step is to go back to the shopkeeper with the pen and the receipt to ask for a replacement or refund.

subtopics.title: Day 6: Role-Play Activity
subtopics.content:
Putting Knowledge into Action

Today is about building confidence! By role-playing common scenarios, you can practice asserting your consumer rights politely and effectively. This also helps you understand the seller's perspective.

Activity Instructions:

Pair up with a classmate. One person will be the 'Customer' and the other will be the 'Shopkeeper'. Act out one of the following scenarios:

  • Scenario 1: The MRP Overcharge. The shopkeeper is charging ₹5 more than the MRP on a cold drink.
  • Scenario 2: The Defective Product. The customer wants to return a t-shirt that has a hole they discovered after purchase.
  • Scenario 3: The Forced Bundle. The shopkeeper is forcing the customer to buy a notebook with a pen they don't want.

The customer should calmly state the problem and their right. The shopkeeper can either agree or refuse, allowing the customer to practice how to respond. Remember, polite but firm communication is the most effective approach.

practice_questions.question: In a role-play, if a shopkeeper refuses to give a refund for a defective product, what should the 'customer' say or do next?
practice_questions.answer: The customer should calmly state that they will escalate the issue by filing a complaint with the consumer forum and mention that they have the receipt as proof.

subtopics.title: Day 7: Revision and Assessment
subtopics.content:
Your Consumer Rights Toolkit

Let's review the key rights we've learned this week. Being an aware consumer is a lifelong skill that protects you and promotes a fair marketplace for everyone.

Your Rights at a Glance:

  • Right to Safety: Protection from hazardous goods.
  • Right to be Informed: Access to information about quality, quantity, price, etc.
  • Right to Choose: Freedom to select from a variety of goods and services.
  • Right to be Heard: Your complaints must be listened to.
  • Right to Seek Redressal: Right to get compensation for unfair trade practices.
  • Right to Consumer Education: The right to acquire knowledge and skills to be an informed consumer.

Remember the national consumer helpline number: 1915. Don't hesitate to use it to raise your voice against unfair practices.

practice_questions.question: What is the national consumer helpline number in India?
practice_questions.answer: The national consumer helpline number is 1915.

lessons.title: Module 11: Basic Law for Teens
lessons.description: Introduction to Rights & Responsibilities, Cyber Laws, and Legal Awareness

subtopics.title: Day 1: Introduction to Law and the Legal System
subtopics.content:
The Rulebook for Society

Law is a system of rules that society creates and enforces to regulate behavior and maintain order. Think of it like the rules of a game—they exist to make sure everyone can play fairly and safely. Without laws, there would be chaos.

Types of Laws That Affect You:

  • Criminal Law: Deals with serious offenses like theft, assault, or cyberbullying.
  • Civil Law: Handles disputes between individuals or organizations, like a contract disagreement or a faulty product.
  • Constitutional Law: Protects your fundamental rights, such as the right to equality and freedom of speech.

Rights vs. Responsibilities

Your rights and responsibilities are two sides of the same coin. You have the right to be safe, and you have the responsibility not to harm others. Understanding this balance is key to being a good citizen.

practice_questions.question: What is the main purpose of having laws in society?
practice_questions.answer: To protect people and their property, maintain order, ensure fairness, and help resolve disputes peacefully.

subtopics.title: Day 2: Understanding Rights - What You're Entitled To
subtopics.content:
Your Shield of Protection

As a citizen, and especially as a young person, you are entitled to certain fundamental rights that protect your dignity and freedom. Knowing these rights is the first step to defending them.

Key Rights to Know:

  • Right to Equality: You cannot be discriminated against based on your religion, race, gender, or place of birth.
  • Right to Freedom of Speech & Expression: You have the right to share your opinions, but this right comes with the responsibility to not spread hate or cause harm.
  • Right to Education: You have a right to access education.
  • Right to Safety: You have a right to be protected from physical and emotional harm, including bullying and harassment, both online and offline.
  • Right to Privacy:g> Your personal information and communications should be protected from unwarranted intrusion.

Special legal protections exist for minors because the law recognizes that young people are still developing.

practice_questions.question: What should you do if your right to education is violated?
practice_questions.answer: You can report it to school authorities, educational boards, or child rights organizations.

subtopics.title: Day 3: Understanding Responsibilities - What You Owe Society
subtopics.content:
The Social Contract

Being part of a society is a two-way street. In exchange for the rights and protections society gives you, you have responsibilities to uphold. This is the 'social contract' that allows us all to live together peacefully.

Your Key Responsibilities:

  • Obey Laws: This is the most basic duty of a citizen.
  • Respect Others' Rights: Your right to swing your arm ends where another person's nose begins. Respect their property, privacy, and opinions.
  • Do Not Bully or Harass: You have a responsibility to create a safe environment for others, both online and offline.
  • Be Accountable: Take responsibility for your actions and learn from your mistakes.

Fulfilling your responsibilities builds trust, character, and a stronger, fairer community for everyone.

practice_questions.question: What to do if you break something at a friend’s house?
practice_questions.answer: Take responsibility, apologize, and offer to pay for or replace the item.

subtopics.title: Day 4: Cyber Laws - Digital Rights and Responsibilities
subtopics.content:
The Law Follows You Online

The digital world is not a lawless space. The same laws and ethical rules that apply offline also apply online. Digital crimes have real-world consequences.

Key Cyber Laws to Know:

  • Cyberbullying & Harassment: Repeatedly targeting, threatening, or humiliating someone online is a serious offense.
  • Identity Theft: Creating fake profiles or using someone else's information without permission is illegal.
  • Copyright Infringement: You cannot legally copy and distribute music, movies, images, or writing without permission. 'Downloading movies illegally' is a form of this.
  • Online Fraud: This includes phishing scams, fake online stores, and other attempts to trick people out of their money.

Your digital footprint is largely permanent. Think before you post, share, or click.

practice_questions.question: Is sharing embarrassing photos without consent legal?
practice_questions.answer: No, it can be considered a form of harassment or cyberbullying and may have legal consequences.

subtopics.title: Day 5: Social Media and Gaming Laws
subtopics.content:
The Terms of Service Agreement

When you sign up for a social media platform or an online game, you are agreeing to a legal contract: the Terms of Service. These rules govern what you can and cannot do on the platform.

Key Things to Understand:

  • Age Restrictions: Most platforms have a minimum age (usually 13) to protect younger users. Creating an account with a fake age is a violation of this contract.
  • Content Moderation: Platforms have the right and responsibility to remove content that violates their policies on hate speech, harassment, or misinformation.
  • Data Collection: The terms outline what data the platform collects about you and how they use it.
  • In-Game Purchases: Laws are evolving around things like 'loot boxes' in games, as some view them as a form of gambling for minors.

It's your responsibility to understand and abide by these rules.

practice_questions.question: What legal steps should you consider if starting a business on social media?
practice_questions.answer: You need to follow the platform's commercial use policies, be honest in advertising, and handle customer data securely.

subtopics.title: Day 6: Case Studies and Real-World Applications
subtopics.content:
When Digital Actions Go to Court

Let's look at how these laws are applied in the real world. In many places, the legal system treats young offenders differently, focusing on rehabilitation over punishment.

Case Examples:

  • Cyberbullying: A case of severe online harassment could lead to legal charges, but the focus would likely be on counseling and restorative justice rather than jail time for a minor.
  • Viral Video: A student who records and shares a private, embarrassing video of a classmate could face legal consequences for invasion of privacy.
  • Academic Fraud: Using AI to cheat or plagiarizing content can not only lead to school suspension but also harm your reputation for future college and job applications.

The key takeaway is that even if the intent was just a 'joke,' the impact on the victim is what matters, and digital actions have serious consequences.

practice_questions.question: How can you support a friend who is a victim of cyberbullying?
practice_questions.answer: Listen to them, save evidence, help them report it to trusted adults and the platform, and offer emotional support.

subtopics.title: Day 7: Mock Court Activity and Review
subtopics.content:
You Be the Judge

Today's activity is a mock court trial to put everything you've learned into practice. This role-play will help you understand the legal process from different perspectives.

The Case:

After an argument, a student secretly records an embarrassing video of another student in the gym and posts it online, where it goes viral.

The Roles:

  • Judge: Oversees the trial and ensures fairness.
  • Prosecution: Argues that the student broke the law (e.g., invasion of privacy, harassment).
  • Defense: Argues on behalf of the accused student.
  • Jury: Listens to the evidence and decides the outcome.

The Process:

The trial will include opening statements, witness testimony, and closing arguments. This activity highlights the complexity of legal issues, the importance of evidence, and why prevention through education is always better than punishment.

practice_questions.question: In the mock trial, what evidence could prove an intent to harm?
practice_questions.answer: Evidence could include threatening messages sent before the incident, captions on the video, or testimony about the argument.
